description:
There is a lot to unpack here... figuratively. There wasn't actually much in the box itself. Wendell really likes this card though! Thanks, NVIDIA for sending us one to test!

More info on the forum! https://forum.level1techs.com/t/nvidia-rtx-5090-has-launched/224532

Check out PugetSystems! https://www.pugetsystems.com/

0:00 Intro
0:40 The Hook
1:34 Physical Specs
5:56 The Big Picture and Frame Generation
12:43 Power Consumption
14:40 It hertz
21:04 Our Benchmarks
28:45 NVIDIA Broadcast and AI
30:44 Conclusion and Final Thoughts

You can find us...
Twitter - https://twitter.com/level1techs
Twitch - https://twitch.tv/teampgp
Patreon - https://www.patreon.com/level1

For all our website links and more, check out our link tree!
https://linktr.ee/level1techs

Thank you for watching!

Edited by Autumn
Benchmarks/Graphs by Amber

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
*IMPORTANT* Any email lacking level1techs.com should be ignored and immediately reported to Queries@level1techs.com.

While it's theoretically possible, I'm not sure there will ever be an option for frame generation to simply compensate to reach a specified frame rate. Its probably doable but significantly more complex. In many gamesif not mostyou can't even use frame generation alongside V-sync, though I believe there's a workaround to bypass that restriction.

Additionally, the GPU would constantly need to reassess and recalculate which frames to AI-generate and when, since the number of natively rendered frames would typically fluctuate quite a bit.

The 5000 series gpu should now be dubbed the "youtuber edition". Because theyre the only ones isolated by any of these real world problems - price, availability, free shipping and exceptional direct product support -- and maybe sponsorship fees.

We only get hyped by feeding us their glowing reviews of these sponsored product and some very mild psa from them - as to not offend their paying sponsors while showing placebo effect of public service to their audience.

These reviews are just ads for nvidia and are no different from any other paid review ads. So now, not only do we have fake frames, we also get disingenuous hyping of products as well in the guise of a review.

Us normal consumers have to contend with hyper inflated prices, very low availability and lack of support when these items break.

Consider this, what would these youtubers say if they didnt get any sponsorship from nvidia or buy cards from general retail to "review"? We might instead get 15 second psa's of tldr and a delayed product review.

Though i guess at the end of the day, content creation is now just a business by itself and a very competitive one at that. Exposure and being the "first" and gaining engagement is one of the keys to their revenue -- aside from sponsorships, let alone patreon donations

comments.author: @stevencharette7918

comments.text: It's not a risk, it's the only option because TSMC haven't improved on process node. So it's not like there was even a choice. Moore's law is dead. This is why the push for AI but the current implementations of AI to graphics are extremely crude and primitive. The end goal is 100% "frame gen" in which the source/base frame is entirely AI generated (which doesn't require AI upscaling nor AI "fake frame gen".) But we're at least a couple of decades away from that. Between now and then, we're going to see an increasing percentage of base frame jobs that are traditionally done via brute force rasterization and ray tracing to achieve, via AI instead. The nvidia neural materials are going to be the first primitive implementation of such a transition. We're going to see the Theseus's ship of computer graphics slowly transition from traditional rendering to 100% AI but it's going to be very gradual as it's going to take time to create and integrate on them. AI in this way has a Moore's law path that is independent of process node improvement Moore's law curve. And since Moore's law is dying, AI is the logical solution and boy is it going to save us and bring with it a multiple orders of magnitude increase to real-time graphics. Nvidia has bet hard having seen the writing on the wall for the last decade and it's going to save computer graphics as with everything else that has been heavily process node advancement dependent for improvements. Moore's Law is (almost) dead......Long live Turing's Law!
comments.author: @DrR1pper

comments.text:
I think it would be kind of hard for the GPU to just randomly generate frames in random spots because that would make things a little stuttery I would think. 

I'm no expert but I would assume that the frames have to be put in a consistent order. 

That being said, I'm not home right now so I can't look but see if there's an auto setting for frame generation.

I play a game called once human and it has Auto in the selection under the frame generation toggle. I'm not exactly sure what Auto does but I'm assuming it makes a decision on when to use frame generation and when not to. It's probably based on your vsync or whatever Target frame rate that you want. 

But I still don't think that the GPU can have the game render 100 regular frames and then 3 frame generated frames and then 20 regular and then five frame generated frames. I think that that would just make a very stuttering mess. 

But I am no engineer so I don't really know how it all works at its core.

comments.text:
It is of course a valid assessment to consider how the card performs for current gaming technologies, but what I am really looking forward to is the integration of AI into the render engine. What I mean is bringing the AI some steps back in the pipeline. As far as I understand it, the current implementation is still to render frames (raster, ray tracing) and then add AI image-to-image processing. I'd really like to see the AI working directly on the 3D geometry, material, illumination information as part of the render engine, rather than working on the 2D output of it (think of a 3D control-net if You will). E.g. I'd love to render with a version of iray which combines a tunable fidelity to the geometry-materials-illumination with AI generation of the rendered image. But it could apply to RT rendering as well, namely games, VR...
I do not expect that this is behind the corner, but what we get from this generation of Nvidia cards might push in that direction, and I am glad they do.
At some point there won't be the case of discussing genuine/real rendered frames and fake AI generated frames, we might not be there yet, but I think this is the right direction to take.

comments.text:
The thing is, people bought the 4090 when it was being sold for WAY more than 4090. Nobody cared. The other thing is that percentages are tricky. The bigger the numbers get the more deceiving they can be. The amount of increase in fps has been pretty standard. But as the numbers go up, the percentage gets smaller. For example a gpu that starts at 50 fps and increases in performance by 50 fps per generation will have a 100% gain in generation 2, but only a 50% gain by gen 3. By gen 4 the gain is only 25%. However the chart would read 50 fps - 100 fps - 150 fps - 200 fps.

I also think the technology in the 5090 is extremely exciting. Developers havent even cracked the surface of whats going to be possible with this tech. And look at Nvidia just announced for the entire RTX line: DLSS 4 is on the way. That breathes new life into all Nvidia RTX gpu s. So much of the future is going to be based on software updates. Nobody saw DLSS 4 for older cards, because it wasnt supposed to be possible with the hardware. Now its arriving in less than a week. Imagine whats going to be possible with the new 5000 series tech in 6 months, or a year. The neural rendering tech by itself looks nuts.

I can understand that not everyone wants to upgrade. Especially if you have a 4090. I only have 3060ti though so Im going to grab a 5090 if I can.

comments.text:
Frame generation is a sensible choice to make when you have high quality frames from which to interpolate and a high base framerate.
Upscaling with severe visual artefacting to the point that when you turn off the pre-requisite setting for that upscaling(TAA) you can see frankly disgusting visuals masked only by the fact that the entire visual experience is fundamentally blurred is not what I'd like to interpolate from. The frames are low quality. The motion is lower quality. Interpolation can not help with motion clarity when there is no motion clarity to preserve.

I've stopped buying newer games because I cannot stand low quality visuals. These assets are wasted. These games are wasted. I would rather never play a new AAA game again than deal with this. I want clarification on 80% of gamers using DLSS. 80% have used DLSS once ever? Responsible dislike of technology requires testing, and I would be considered an FSR or DLSS gamer because of that, however I had to see what is wrong before I could join the F TAA crowd. I now turn off TAA and its derivatives in any game I play at any cost to visual quality and I will only tolerate native rendering, end of story. Well-implemented interpolation on the other hand is great and has been the next step in motion fluidity being talked about on sites like Blur Busters for at least 4-5 years.

well I will buy a 5090 (hope to get one next week) for my 9800x3D gaming setup. I bought a 32" 4k 240hz QD-OLED monitor in the summer and already built my 9800x3D pc in November. I have a 1070 in there, waiting to get replaced with a 5090. 

I decided a year ago, that I dont care anymore; I just want the best gaming performance technically possible. Since the 60 series is probably coming with a node jump, we can expect a bigger performance uplift than we get now with 5090 vs 4090. So Im already expecting to switch up my 5090 to a 6090 when that one gets released lol.

And regarding my CPU - Ive already known and also seen new benchmark that prove it again, that you can and will absolutely be CPU-limited in some games, even with a 9800x3D and even on a 4k monitor, especially bc DLSS Upscaling will basically always be on in my games. Frame Gen depends on the game and how many FPS I get without it. But DLSS Upscaling, specifically DLSS Quality (so 1440p internal resolution) already looked basically like native 4k or better to me and the new transformer DLSS model should look even better, so I expect it to be even more incredible, which reinforces my stance on using DLSS Upscaling in virtually every game that doesnt run at 4k 240 FPS without it. (and btw - DLSS Upscaling reduces latency between frames, since its an actual performance and rendered fps increase, its not just a visual motion smoothing technology like Frame Generation). So I will usually render at 1440p with my 5090, that puts me into a CPU bottleneck in many games, so I will def upgrade my CPU as well to a 11800x3D or whatever it will be called.

comments.text:
Once the rest of the stack releases, I do want to see someone perform an experiment.  5090 with no AI features vs the lowest card with the same architecture with the AI features.   But not just on-paper benchmarks, I want to see this as a blind test, with esports people who are above average with reaction timing, your typical gamer (different genres of games would make this interesting), and seek out visual forensic people that're the Spot The Difference world champions.  At least then we'd have some actual data on the debate rather than just typical on-rails benchmarking and demos. 

Also I'm curious how you could even run two of these in the same case.  Wouldn't the exhaust from one just tank the performance of the second?  You'd need a case design where you basically have opposing cards just to get the airflow to behave and not hinder one card, and nobody offers that.  Though there may be an oddball case (likely meant for server rack usage) that might have two slots side by side rather than stacked, this is the only other solution to get airfllow to behave, though in this stylo of case you're likely to choke out the cards due to obvious reasons.  I know SLI was abandoned long ago and multi-GPU has been hit or miss since, but these flow-through coolers severely hinder the idea of multiple cards. 

Though, it will be interesting to see what water cooling does, especially with the location of the PCB.  I'm also personally interested in seeing what can be done with the card since it has that connector on the PCIe foot, repositioning the PCB via a new foot could be extremely interesting and has a ton of potential for various implementations; though I hope this connector eventually spirals into being the next unofficial MXM standard, SFF and laptops could benefit from this, especially as Dell seems to intorduce 'swappable graphics' just to abandon it as we're on, what, the third iteration of Dell doing this since MXM's death.  Personally I really want to see someone put two (or three?) 5090 boards side by side, single slot on carrier frame, figure out the I/O situation as its also on a FPC, water cooled, and utilizing this board connector to have a riser that jumps the remote motherboard PCIe slots.  I also have hopes that this connector is the way forward on desktop, the PCIe slot is so outdated, server companies (at least Supermicro) have shown that a higher pitch (double to be exact) is viable for slotted cards, even m.2 is double the pitch of PCIe, but I think the real solution is not only higher pitch but also more rowas of connectors as that increases overall density and improves footprint efficiency; for example, this board connector is four rows of pins

comments.text: I don't understand what kind of non-integer scaling for framerate your are envisioning. If your GPU is capable of generating 90fps natively, there is no clean way to pad that up to 120fps, as the frame time intervals will necessarily will have to become inconsistent. This should materialise as stuttering or "micro judder".
comments.author: @coolcat23

comments.text:
At each monitor tick it gets latest native frame. If it is the same as previous then get the generated frame. 
You discard generated frames that weren't needed. 
Gpu have to be aware when next monitor tick happen and swap buffer accordingly. 
If gpu know when tick happened it can then swap that buffer with generated frame. Next time if another native is ready it swaps it again before another monitor tick.

I guess freesync works in one way ie gpu telling monitor to display another frame and it would have to be bidirectional, so the monitor telling gpu to swap.
comments.author: @damianabregba7476

comments.text: @damianabregba7476 First, "If it is the same as previous..." will be true every time because the GPU isn't capable of delivering at the monitor refresh rate. Only in the special case where the GPU can normally match the monitor frequency and only in some cases drops below, your scheme would deviate from 2x frame generation. That's not the scenario Wendell was discussing. Second, if you sometimes use generated frames and sometimes not, you get inconsistent frame time intervals which will not result in smooth motion.

comments.text:
Given that wendell cannot/does not show the setting used, it's likely this is part of the embargo. Especially the beta for CP2077 and how the DLSS override requires beta support which is not public yet, sic. Likely they do not want speculation on a feature to 'fiddle' with game engine render path, i.e. reshade type injection.

e.g. despite DLSS override, we don't see it in action. 

The example of MFG, at what looks like 4x, is one of three games with beta DLSS 4 support where we don't see settings. 

keep that in mind when the 5080 reviews and the embargo fully lifts around the 29/30th.  There's a reason he can't show the settings and thats due to the 'secret sauce' on MFG.

He's also getting mid 50s in cp2077 4k, which 4x/3x's to 204/160 ish. which means the sync was being affected by the 3x MFG and 4x MFG with power usage too, and, when he's toggled to 120fps ... it's not clear which MFG was set. 3x or 4x. 

When it hits 120fps, this is with regular DLSS  frame injection at perhaps 3x or 4x. It's not stated. Reading between the lines a bit, 3x should be ~165 fps, lowering the system to 120, means it's rendering at 40fps to get 120 as a target fps. At 4x, it would render at 30fps to get 120fps. 

If that's how it's working, there will be a need to toggle the setting in the game to hypervise if it's using injected frames. And, you can probably interpret, 60fps target with MFG will reduce the engine's render sync to 20fps or 15fps. Which will be fascinating to test how the 5070's perform in a game that's running at 15fps. 

When the 5080 review comparisons come out, you'll probably see what the intended comparison was meant to be talking about with internal vsync and external vsync targets.

comments.text:
This is how res scaling/frame gen should work.  Any game that cannot fit roughly within the guidelines isn't worth one dollar of our money and GPUs shouldn't be advertised based on the features that should not be used  at launch as they are for attempting to emulate a more consistent performance thru the products lifespan.
5080 gets 120fps at 1440p native.  You can enable res scaling and frame gen, but choose not to because of the degraded experience and you are already getting the high quality experience you paid for.
4080 gets 90 fps at 1440p native but you can enable res scaling to increase that to 120 if you're OK with lower image quality and image stability.
3080 gets 60 fps at 1440p native but you can enable res scaling and single FG to increase that to 120 if you're OK with lower image quality, lower image stability and higher latency.  It is upgrade time if you are not. 
2080 needs res scaling to obtain 60fps 1440p but you can enable multi FG to increase that to 120 if you're OK with much lower image quality, much lower image stability and higher latency.  It is upgrade time if you are not.

comments.text:
@bosstowndynamics5488 "is both a tautology and outright false, since, y'know, the 4090 has a configurable power target"

First off, it isn't a tautology because its not just repeating itselfits a claim that can actually be challenged or disproven..... A tautology here would be :

"The 4090 is powerful because its powerful"

"y'know, the 4090 has a configurable power target"

Both cards have configurable power targets, but that doesnt change the fact that the 4090 inherently requires more power to reach its maximum potential. The configurable power target doesnt invalidate the reality of its higher TDP.

"Nvidia could have made the 4080 as the flagship what with that being lower power yet faster than the previous flagship"

Would have been a huge mistake to, the 4080 is only about 16 - 22% faster then a 3090ti..... Now 3080 vs 4080 was a very good choice because the 4080 around 50% faster then a 3080....

"An example of TDP target going down but performance target going up from the AMD side is the R9 Fury X vs Vega 64  "

Talking to you might actually fry my brain. You do realize the R9 Fury X was built on a 28nm process, right? The Vega 64, on the other hand, was built on a 14nm process. Thats a full-node shrink, which explains the huge uplift in performance and efficiency. They went from 28nm to 14nm in a single generationthats a monumental hardware change.

For the Nvidia ones same story
GTX 280 -> GTX 285: 65nm -> 55nm process.
GTX 480 -> GTX 680: 40nm -> 28nm process.
GTX 700 -> GTX 10 series: 28nm -> 16nm process.

You getting it yet mate? In every case, these werent minor tweaksthey were massive leaps in semiconductor manufacturing, often skipping over 10nm or more in process size between generations.

Weve gone from 8nm (RTX 30-series) to 4nm/5nm (RTX 40-series). While thats impressive, the gains from modern process shrinks arent as dramatic as they used to be. Were not skipping 10nm+ nodes anymore, and efficiency improvements are far smaller. You simply wont see the same kind of TDP reductions alongside performance gains like in the past.
comments.author: @aflyingcowboy31

comments.text:
@bosstowndynamics5488 "only that an increase in TDP has never been historically required to keep advancing performance and that there have been drops before."

We don't live in the past anymore, we are nearing actual processor size limits, we aren't skipping over 10nm or more in process size between generations like we were a decade or so ago.... Were approaching the physical limits of how small processors can get, and the performance-per-watt gains from these advancements have diminished drastically compared to a decade ago.

"The decision to start cranking up power with Ampere was based on wanting a card"

No, it was based on the fact that we don't have a choice if we want to see actual performance increases that aren't 20-30% improvements. Smaller process nodes like 4nm or 5nm are expensive to produce, and the efficiency gains they provide dont justify sticking to modest uplifts. If were paying these premium prices, consumers expect massive generational leaps, which is why the industry has leaned into higher power draw.

FYI you seem to forget even AMD had to crank up the power for their cards last gen.

"it was not a mandatory part of delivering a generational improvement for anything other than Blackwell really."

It absolutely is mandatory going forward unless theres a major technological breakthrough. The days of massive efficiency gains from process shrinks are behind us. The jump from 4nm/5nm to 3nm (or even 2nm) wont provide dramatic improvements in either performance or power efficiency. After that, were looking at 1.4nm processors, but those arent expected until at least 20282030.

comments.text:
@bosstowndynamics5488 "The 4090 is powerful because its powerful" 

This is a tautology, why? Because the conclusion and premise are the same i.e. I am repeating the same idea in a different way without explaining why the 4090 is powerful.

" The 4090 requires that much power because of how powerful it is."

This isn't a tautology as I am making a causal claim. I am linking the high power consumption of the 4090 to its performance/powerfulness.

There is no tautology in my original statement because the terms "power" and "powerful" are not the same. "Power" refers to electricity consumption, while "powerful" describes the performance of the GPU. These are distinct concepts and are not being used interchangeably.

A better more simplified example of a tautology might be: "The sky is blue because its blue".
comments.author: @aflyingcowboy31

comments.text:
@aflyingcowboy31 Pick at least one:
1) your statement was a tautology ("The 4090 needs power because it's powerful" with powerful referring to high power consumption) 
2) your statement was objectively wrong ("The 4090 needs power because it's powerful" with powerful referring to compute power - this is objectively wrong because it ignores both that the 4090 can run with less power input while still delivering a lot of performance (even if it is a bit less) and other hardware that's much more efficient (eg the RTX4000 is something like 2-4 times as efficient in terms of compute per unit power), ie "powerful" from a compute perspective doesn't inherently mandate "high power consumption"

Either way it's not a particularly interesting line of reasoning when discussing GPU architecture because the thing that is of most interest with architecture is efficiency, either in terms of die area or in terms of power consumption (since power and die area wind up being the caps on absolute performance), getting hung up on a specific example instead of the broader picture of Blaxkwell vs Ada Lovelace vs Ampere misses the point

comments.author: @TamasJantyik

comments.text:
@TamasJantyik Mostly, although it's less that it looks better because it's more expensive and more that the things they do to make it look better are more computationally expensive. The little 3 dollar chips in TVs aren't using deep learning models to interpret and redraw the frames to create predicted interval frames. It's also worth noting that DLSS doesn't need to backfill - interpolation requires you to take the last frame and the next frame and fill in the gap, which means you need to be rendering a couple frames ahead of where the display is up to. That's trivial for a video stream, it's a big problem for interactive media. 

That's not to say that frame gen is amazing or anything, as you say they're still fake frames that are generated using a method other than actually creating the view for that frame using the game engine, but there is at least some technical reasons why you would want to do this the hard way instead of the cheap way if you want generated frames

comments.text: @KevinHorroxYou should really look up what a bottleneck is. The entire point of a CPU bottleneck is that if the CPU is running as fast as it can then adding more GPU power doesn't add much overall performance, so the differences get minimised. You can see this in GN's testing where the 5090 was only a little faster than the 4090 at 1080p but way faster at 4K. That effect gets worsened with a slower CPU since the fastest rate the CPU can feed frames to the GPU is lower so you hit that ceiling sooner.

comments.text:
This frame generation stuff really becomes interesting when you start thinking about 1000hz displays and beyond (TCL already demoed one last year, we are getting 500hz QD OLEDs and 750hz LCDs this year). You can render at 60-120fps, interpolate 4x to 480fps, and then on top of that you can use Electron-Beam Emulation (advanced BFI that more closely resembles a CRT scan) to get CRT-like motion performance.

You lose out on brightness, but thankfully you only use a small part of the display (so higher nits output before ABL-limiters kick in), and luckily the industry is headed towards 10,000nits and beyond for HDR. But, the more you "refresh the screen", or how many frames you have before the electron beam emulation, the less brightness you lose because the time a part of the frame is black lowers, without losing motion performance. So having a 4x increase in frames is definitely helpful. (It's basically like ULMB2/G-Sync Pular, though that uses the backlight to increase motion performance)

VR headsets already employ some impulse techniques, because motion blur is one of the main causes of VR-sickness. When the resolution increases, the need for better motion performance increases as well. This makes sense if you realize that a UFO test at 1000pixels/sec on a 1000hz display gets 1ms of persistence blur (the blur buster law), but if that UFO moves at 3000pixels/sec on a 1000hz display you get 3ms of blur. At 8k, this is less than half of your display, so you would need 2 times the motion performance of a 4k screen to match it. Even 1000hz isn't close to being enough to get perfect motion.

Nvidia is on the right track here, rendering 1000 fps or more is just not a reasonable thing to ask. This only makes sense if you have a high base frame-rate. Even the 5080 is unneedlessly hampered in terms of rasterization performance from what I can deduct, interpolation is not the answer to this problem. If we can expect 10% increase over 4080 as per Nvidia's graphs, then games like Cyberpunk with PT will still dip below 50 often enough to be annoying. It's only helpful if you have enough frame rate, but not enough to fill your ultra high refresh screen.

I don't care about that at all and I'm not going to pretend like I do either.
I can work more and save up for more money, if it gets too hot I can just upgrade the AC, but I can't just get my brain to perceive 120 fps as smooth continuous motion nor can I eliminate the motion sickness I experience when trying to game while being limited to such frame rates.
All I want is 4x SLI (and enough direct PCIe lanes to enable it) and the ability to use non-AFR modes, even if that meant each successive GPU only decreased the raw frametimes by 20-30%, since it would similarly reduce latency and eliminate microstuttering to boot!

comments.text:
It's not so easy, as FG/interpolation is pretty "dumb" in that when a frame is rendered it paces out the next real frame and fills in the steps in between using interpolation. This is by design for the sake of frame pacing and latency. 

If you get 4FPS, it knows that the next frame will be rendered in 250ms, so with a 2X interpolation it knows it has to pace the generated frame at 125ms, but it does this opaquely to the renderer and just fills in the framebuffer blindly, you can't easily control the amount of frames generated without messing up the frame pacing. Maybe if you increase the amount of interpolation, this becomes easier to control. This is also exactly why V-Sync has such a huge latency penalty with frame generation.

The smart part about DLSS/FSR FG is that it applies motion vector data and smart algorithms to fill in those frames.
comments.author: @hugevibez

comments.text: @hugevibez I wonder how much added lag would be introduced if insted the GPU AI stuff pulled from a "native frame buffer" then using the motion and vector data to increase the frame rate to that of the display. This would decouple the native FPS and the output FPS.
comments.author: @jeposton

comments.text: @hugevibez Exactly. Even if latency is higher with framegen, it's CONSISTENTLY higher. In the scenario of using it only when the framerate is below X, latency would be all over the map. It's super easy for our brains to adjust to latency if it's consistent, but inconsistent latency would feel incredibly jarring, much like how micro stutter from bad 1% lows is more noticeable than low overall framerate.

comments.text:
Exactly! In the meantime, we're just going to have to manually dial it in, for each game individually. Start off with max RT on with Ray Reconstruction etc., look at the frame rate (e.g. ~50Hz), tweak settings (e.g. RT options, or upscaling if required) to reach minimum base 60Hz (to ensure decent base latency), then compare with your monitor's max refresh rate (e.g. 120Hz), see that you need to just double the frames (DLSS MFG x 2 to smooth) to get up to your monitor's refresh rate of 120Hz, etc. That way you only need to use the minimum amount of DLSS upscaling and MFG required, maximising latency and image quality.

Given that you are maximising latency and image quality whilst trying to reach your monitor's max refresh rate, you should have a game setting that, once you've locked in the base image quality settings and DLSS upscaling balancing latency and quality (I wouldn't trust a game engine to do this automatically...), you can set the target frame rate (e.g. 120Hz) and enable a setting for the game to dynamically choose whether to use MFG if required to reach the max monitor refresh rate.

comments.text: It would be nice if that happened, but I kind of doubt it will anytime soon. AI models aren't typically very flexible about the shape of their inputs and outputs. I mean, the training dataset Nvidia uses to build the model likely uses a very specific number of direction vectors per pixel group and a single frame as input with three frames as output. Meaning, DLSS 4 probably can not output any fewer than 3 frames per generation. It is similar to the whole "How many Rs are there in the word strawberry?" thing that stumps non-reasoning LLMs. A 'get me to this target FPS with as many real frames as possible' approach seems to me like it would add a significant layer of complexity to the process. Just a guess though.

If this was true companies wouldn't invest so much money in architecture development, there would never be performance regressions, and most importantly there would never be improvements in performance or efficiency outside of node changes, yet every one of those is demonstrably false (before they stagnated Intel was even famous for their relentless tick tock cadence where every generation of early Core processors saw substantial performance uplift even though they alternated between a process change and an architecture change, so literally every architecture change was on the same process and yet they kept getting improvements).

That's not to say that the performance improvements from architecture are going to be massive in the future, but the idea that we've already discovered the optimal rasterisation and ray tracing pipelines is comical in a world where the much, much more mature x86 architecture is still seeing substantial architectural improvements separate to process node (GPUs are more complex and much less understood)
comments.author: @bosstowndynamics5488

comments.author: @Stef3m

comments.text:
@bobalazsgaming Idle power consumption is important for a few reasons: 
1) it's an indicator of overall power efficiency, this thing needs nearly 50W just to show a static Windows desktop
2) Most PCs spend at least some time idle
3) The GPU can be close to idle even when the PC isn't (eg web browsing)
4) These GPUs are increasingly going into small servers and render boxes for AI stuff in situations where they're being used for intermittent loads - in that situation the server is probably going to be left on and idling in between tasks so that it's available and ready whenever the user wants to send a job to it, and in many of those cases there will be more than one (see Wendell's own plan to buy 2 more for a total of 3)

@alison9870 It's not an nvidia vs amd thing. It's a chiplet vs monolithic thing. The only drawback is latency, which is probably why nvidia is still on monolithic, and that approach is clearly approaching it's end (600 watts, regardless of how well the die is cooled, is still 600 watts inside a case).

I'm not sure about the whole "using as many real frames as possible und use framegen to make up the rest". 
I mean sure it seems like an obvious choice at first. But if you have 100 real frames and add 20 fake frames, where would you put the fake frames? Probably equi-distant, right? I'm just spitballing here, I guess you'd have to test it to find out for sure.

comments.text:
@D3G00N ??? Driver installation does not record feature usage in game.  Only in-game activation and usage records as usage databelieve it or not DLSS is a HUGE performance lift for lower tier cards, so it's a GOOD thing that it's enabled because it allows MORE people to experience higher fidelty in framerate, resolution and smothness in game. So of course a lot of people would use it. 

Also DLSS isn't some "add-on" you can just tack on to a driver or game like browser extension.  It has to integrated into the core functionality of the how the game engine produces frames. It's not just in the driver, or GC firmware, so they can record it's usage and functionality from a hardware and software stack. If they're talking about driver installations, they're talking about driver installations, if they're talking about usage, they're talking about usage.
comments.author: @SterlingSanders

comments.text:
...wait till he realizes that DLSS is just in-frame generation vs new frame generation. The DLSS "frame" you're seeing isn't the REAL frame either sir. It's not some some conspiracy or trick they're trying to pull on you. The reason they talk about them together is that they serve the same purpose and work in concert with each other: they both allow hardware to perform beyond it's raw performance capability to increase the fidelity, smoothness, playability, and framerate of the software they're embedded into. 

One uses AI to upscale a lower resolution image, the other uses AI to smooth the transition between frames by creating them. They are a part of the same frame pipeline and AI software stack, so of course they talk about them together.
comments.author: @SterlingSanders

comments.text:
@interstellarsurfer This has nothing to do with skill, some gamers want game developers to cater to their kind of system, which is what opting-in to the survey helps do. It anonymously gives developers the dataa singular timeon the most common kind of systems that are most likely to play their game. Without the data, they have to guess. If you play games, it actually benefits you to opt-in to the survey if prompted, it is not some measure of intelligence or capability. 

Either way, this is the beauty of statistics, you don't need everyone to opt-in to the survey, you just need a representative size of the audienceand steam has far more than that in participants. Steam polls monthly, they don't hold on to the previous data set, so every poll is from scratch, and thus the numbers swing. This is why it's best to look at yearly average results, where the the sample size across the year/multiple years ends up in the 10's of millions. As far as statistics go, trust me, that is more than enough to get a complete understanding of the gaming hardware marketplace at large. You won't find a better, publicly available understanding of gaming hardware then there.
comments.author: @SterlingSanders

comments.text:
@AllSeeingEy3 
LMFAO ..... keep telling yourself that son ...... Maybe you don't, but I remember listening to other Artist (am a commercial 2D and 3D artist) waxing lyrical about how "our jobs were safe, no software could ever replace us" .......... lol
The simple fact is that most of the things some humans constantly congratulate themselves on being the only creators of are nothing more than wide and deep data cross-referencing operations .... Most honest Artist know this since it's our direct experience of being creative and generating ideas ........ they all come from other things you experience, without the background experience there is no creativity ... kind of like how the AI's need data to learn a function...........
All the human exceptionalism stuff is the saddest, most unself-aware cope imaginable. There is no logical argument or empirical or factual data to support any idea that compute cannot do human level tasks, every week we get a new example of it doing exactly that ..... yet guys like you seem superglued to the cope on human exceptionalism, when the direct evidence clearly shows the opposite ... this is somewhat beyond just simply mistaken.

The AI is only going to get better at everything..... good luck being a horse coachman, just as Ford invents the model T. I am sure lots of coachmen, spent lots of time talking about how, the stupid metal boxes could never replace the bond between man and horse ... lol.
